titleStmt.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of HfNbTaTiZrW and HfNbTaTiZrMoW refractory high-entropy alloys

analytic.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of HfNbTaTiZrW and HfNbTaTiZrMoW refractory high-entropy alloys

biblStruct.note: Received 29 January 2019 Received in revised form 27 March 2019 Accepted 11 June 2019

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory high-entropy alloy Crystal structure Microstructure Mechanical properties

div.p: W and Mo are added to the HfNbTaTiZr high entropy alloy to improve its high-temperature performance. Microstructures, and mechanical properties of new refractory high-entropy alloys, HfNbTaTiZrW (H-W) and HfNbTaTiZrMoW (H-MoW), were studied. W and/or Mo additions broaden the two-phases temperature range and introduced two disordered BCC phases in contrast with the single BCC phase in HfNbTaTiZr. Attributing to the dual-phases microstructure and the strong solid solution strengthening effect, H-W and H-MoW exhibit substantially improved yield strengths at 25e1200 C compared with HfNbTaTiZr. Particularly, at 1200 C, H-W and H-MoW show yield strengths of 345 MPa and 703 MPa, which are much higher than 92 MPa of HfNbTaTiZr. No phase change happens during compressive tests at high temperatures, indicating good phase stabilities of H-W and H-MoW alloys.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Since being proposed in 2004, high-entropy alloys (HEAs) [1] has been increasingly investigated due to their high strength [2], high hardness [2], good wear resistance [3], good corrosion resistance [4], and excellent magnetic properties [5]. HEAs break up the design strategy of conventional alloys and employ five or more elements as principal components (rather than just 1 or 2) at molar ratios of 5e35%.

Refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) are mainly composed of the metal elements with melting points higher than 1650 C [6e14]. The first two reported RHEAs are NbMoTaW and NbMo-TaWV which were prepared using vacuum arc melting by Senkov et al., in 2010 [6]. These two RHEAs have a simple BCC disordered solid solution structure [6], and are structurally stable at high temperature [15]. Moreover, compressive yield strengths of these two alloys can still be maintained at 405 MPa and 477 MPa respectively at 1600 C, which is obviously superior to traditional nickel-based superalloys [16,17]. However, these two RHEAs have significant room temperature (RT) brittleness, and their fracture strains are less than 2% at RT [15]. To overcome the RT brittleness, Senkov et al. designed a new RHEA, HfNbTaTiZr, and this alloy exhibits a compressive strain >50% at RT [7]. This superior ductility of HfNbTaTiZr is completely different from the RT brittleness of other RHEAs with BCC structures [15]. HfNbTaTiZr RHEA also showed a stable single-phase BCC structure after annealing at 1200 C, but it decomposed into multiple phases after annealing at intermediate temperatures (500e900 C) [18,19]. Ta and Nb have BCC crystal structures through high temperature to RT, but Hf, Ti and Zr are BCC at high temperature and transform to HCP at 1760 C, 862 C and 882 C, respectively. Therefore, the single BCC phase in HfNbTaTiZr tends to decompose into three phases, the BCC matrix, BCC Ta-Nbrich precipitates, and HCP Zr-Hf-rich precipitates after annealing at 700e800 C. The yield strength of HfNbTaTiZr is much lower than former RHEAs (NbMoTaW and NbMoTaWV), e.g., its yield strength is only 92 MPa at 1200 C [20], which renders this alloy less attractive for high-temperature applications.

In this paper, W and Mo are added to the HfNbTaTiZr RHEA to improve its compressive strength, considering these two elements feature the highest melting points among the four refractory metals (W, Mo, Cr and V) [21]. The increased melting points are expected to elevate softening temperatures of the HfNbTaTiZrW (H-W) and HfNbTaTiZrMoW (H-MoW) RHEAs, and microstructures and mechanical properties of novel H-W and H-MoW alloys are carefully studied in this paper.

div.head: Methods
div.p: Equal-molar H-W and H-MoW RHEAs were prepared with commercial purity (99.9 wt%) Hf, Nb, Ta, Ti, Zr, W using vacuum arc melting in a water-cooled copper crucible under argon atmosphere. Alloys were remelted at least five times to ensure the compositional homogeneity. Compositions of alloys were measured by an Inductive Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent ICPOES730) with a LECO ONH836 elemental analyzer (for O, N, and H) and a vario El cube elemental analyzer (for C), and were shown in Table S1 in Supplementary Information. Impurities in the two alloys are all <0.01 wt%. Solidification paths of alloys were predicted using a Thermo-Calc software and the TCHEA1 database [22]. Crystal structures were examined with a Rigaku Ultima III Xray diffractometer using a Cu-K a radiation and a scanning rate of 5 / min from 20 to 100 . Microstructures of as-cast alloys were studied using an optical microscope (OM), a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S4800) equipped with an Oxford Instruments INCA x-sight energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) and an Oxford HKL Nordlys II Electron Backscattered Diffraction (EBSD), and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20). TEM samples were prepared using a FEI Helios NanoLab 600 Dual-Beam focused ion beam (DB-FIB) system. Quasi-static compression tests at room temperature were conducted on an Instron 5569 universal testing machine with a constant stain rate of 10 À3 /s, and compressive strains were measured by an extensometer. Samples of F4 Â 6 mm were used. Compression tests at 800, 1000, and 1200 C were carried out using a dynamic thermal simulation testing machine (Gleeble-3500) and the furnace chamber was evacuated to 10 -3 torr before each test. Specimens of F6 Â 9 mm were used. The heating rate is 300 C/min and the compressive strain rate is 10 -3 /s. Compressive strains were obtained by directly measuring displacements of indenters.

div.head: Thermodynamic simulation
div.p: Fig. 1 shows solidification paths of HfNbTaTiZr, H-W and H-MoW alloys at the equilibrium state. It can be seen that the liquid H-W alloy (Fig. 1(b)) continues to solidify as a single BCC_A2 phase just below its liquidus (2295 C). As the temperature drops to 1740 C, the single BCC phase starts to decompose into BCC_A2 and BCC_A2#2. These two BCC phases coexist between 1740 C and 971 C, and after then, the Laves and HCP phases form at the expense of BCC_A2 and BCC_A2#2. Five phases, i.e. BCC_A2, BCC_A2#2, Laves phase, HCP_A3, and HCP_A3#2, are predicted in this alloy at room temperature at equilibrium state. Note that phase fractions are not properly shown in Fig. 1(b) under 800 C, this is likely attribute to the limit of TCHEA1 database, e.g. it does not contain all ternary phase diagrams of refractory elements incorporated in the alloy. A similar solidification path can be found for the H-MoW alloy. Comparing with HfNbTaTiZr, additions of the W and/or Mo reduce the temperature range of single-phase BCC (1847-1018 C, 1784-1742 C, 1800-1544 C in HfNbTaTiZr, H-W, and H-MoW alloys respectively), but enlarge the temperature range in which two BCC phases coexist. This is more obvious in H-W (1742-988 C) than in H-MoW (1544-1248 C). Both alloys are predicted to have multiple phases at room temperature after equilibrium solidification, however, due to the fast cooling rate (~160 K/s) in current experiments, it is reasonable to predict that only solid solution phases would form in H-W and H-MoW. Moreover, due to expanded coexistences of two BCC ranges in H-W and H-MoW, it would not be surprised to find two BCC phases in these two as-cast alloys, comparing with only a single BCC phase found in HfNbTa-TiZr, as reported in Ref. [7]. This speculation will be validated in the following experiments.

div.head: Crystal structures and microstructures
div.p: Mixing enthalpy (DH mix ) [23], differences of the atomic sizes (d r ) [23],U-parameter [24], h-parameter [25], f-parameter [26], elastic residual strain root mean square (ε R:M:S ) [27], and intrinsic elastic strain energy (E 2 /E 0 ) [28] were suggested to be necessary requirements needed (but not sufficient) to predict the formation of solid solution in HEAs [29], and valence electron concentration (VEC) [30] is also suggested to be effective to anticipate the crystal structure type. Definitions of these criteria are as following [23e30] and calculated results for our alloys are listed in Table 1:
div.formula: DH mix ¼ X i < j 4H ij c i c j (1) d r ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi X c i ð1 À r i =rÞ 2 q $100%(2)
U ¼ T m DS mix =jDH mix j(3)

h ¼ T ann DS mix =jDH IM j max (4) f ¼ ðDS mix À jDH mix j=T m Þ=jS E j (5) ε R:M:S ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi X c i ε 2 i q (6) E 2 . E 0 ¼ X c u ð1 À r u =rÞ 2 (7) VEC ¼ X c i ðVECÞ i (8
div.p: where c i and r i are the atomic percentage and atomic radius of element i; H ij is an enthalpy of mixing between elements i and j; r is the average atomic radius, which is calculated by r ¼ P c i r i ; T m is the melting point of alloy that is calculated using the rule of mixtures: T m ¼ P c i T mi [24], and T mi is the melting point of element i;

DS mix is the mixing entropy of alloy, calculating asDS mix ¼ À R P c i lnc i [24]; T ann is the annealing temperature used in the experimental setting and could be replaced by some critical temperature (T crit ~0.6T m ) [25]; DH IM is the mixing enthalpy of any two elements in the alloy; S E is the excessive entropy of mixing and can be obtained following the method detailed in Supplementary Information; ε i is the residual strain and its calculation method is in Section 3 on Supplementary Information;c u ¼ c i c j r u ¼ ðr i þ r j Þ=2; and (VEC) i is the valence electron concentration of element i. The data used for calculations are from Refs. [8,31] and some calculated items are listed in Table S2 (Supplementary Information).
It was suggested that, to form a solid solution, the generally
div.formula: accepted criteria are À 16:25kJ=mol DH mix 5kJ=mol, d r 6%, U ! 1, h ! 0:19, f ! 7:0, ε R:M:S 0:061, E 2 =E 0 13:6 Â 10 À4 [29].
div.p: Our calculated results (as shown in Table 1) fall within these ranges, which well predicts that solid solution(s) would form in our alloys. The calculated VEC are 4.4e4.86 (Table 1) and also well consistent with VEC<6, indicating that formed solid solution(s) should exhibit a BCC structure [29]. The mixing enthalpy decreases from a positive value of 2.72 kJ/mol to negative values of À2.11 and À3.59 kJ/mol. This is because that W and Mo are easy to combine with other components. The d r increases as the addition of W and Mo, which is due to smaller atomic radius values of W (r W ¼ 1.41 Å) and Mo (r Mo ¼ 1.36 Å) than the other elements (r Hf ¼ 1.59 Å, r Nb ¼ 1.43 Å, r Ta ¼ 1.47 Å, r Ti ¼ 1.47 Å, r Zr ¼ 1.58 Å). Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of as-cast H-W and H-MoW alloys. Both alloys exhibit two disordered BCC solid solutions, which is consistent with predictions made by both criteria above and CAL-PHAD results in the previous section. As explained later, these two sets of XRD peaks represent interdendrite and dendrite regions, respectively. As shown by typical enlarged peaks in Fig. 2, diffraction peaks of H-MoW move slightly to higher 2q than those of H-W, which is due to the smaller atomic radius of Mo element. Moreover, the addition of Mo weakens the separation of peaks of two BCC. This is because that the Mo element decreases the difference in composition between dendrite regions and interdendrite regions (as explained in Table 2 and Fig. 4). The 'theoretical' lattice parameter can be estimated using rule of mixtures:
div.formula: a mix ¼ X c i a i(9)
div.p: where c i and a i are the concentration and the lattice parameter of element i. EDX measured c i in each phase are given in As shown in Fig. 3, both as-cast H-W and H-MoW alloys exhibit dendritic microstructure. Grain sizes of H-W and H-MoW alloys were also quantified by EBSD as ~29.4 mm and ~31.7 mm, as shown in Fig. S1 in Supplementary Information. Compositions of dendrite and interdendrite regions are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 4. Dendrite regions in the H-W alloy are rich with elements of higher melting points, i.e., W (3423 C), Ta (3014 C), and Nb (2467 C). In contrast, the interdendrite regions are rich with elements of low melting points, i.e., Hf (2227 C), Zr (1852 C), and Ti (1670 C). Similarly, dendrite regions in the H-MoW alloy are rich with W, Ta, and Nb, but lack of Hf, Zr, and Ti. An exception is Mo which is almost homogeneously distributed in the alloy. The degree of segregation in the RHEAs is characterized by the segregation ratio (K):
div.formula: K ¼ ðc dr Þ i ðc id Þ i(10)
div.p: where (c dr ) i and (c id ) i are the atomic percentage of element i in dendrite and interdendrite regions respectively. The larger the difference between 1 (means no segregation) and the K value, the severer the segregation. As shown by K in Table 2, segregations of all compositions in H-W are higher than in H-MoW. This obviously more serious segregations in H-W than in H-MoW can also been clearly seen in Fig. 4. Fig. 5 shows TEM images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of the H-W (Fig. 5 Calculated mixing enthalpy (DH mix ), differences of the atomic sizes (dr ), U-parameter, h-parameter, f-parameter, elastic residual strain root mean square (ε R:M:S Þ, intrinsic elastic strain energy (E 2 /E 0 ), valence electron concentration (VEC), and calculated and measured average lattice parameters of HfNbTaTiZr [7,29] 1).

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Typical compressive stress-strain curves of H-W and H-MoW alloys at various temperatures are shown in Fig. 6. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the H-W alloy exhibits the yield strength of 1550 MPa at RT, and reaches the peak strength (2322 MPa) at ε ¼ 26.3% and fails at ε ¼ 26.3%. Comparing with room-temperature tests, this alloy shows significantly decreased strengths but improved ductility at high temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6 (b) and (c), comparing with H-W, the H-MoW alloy shows increased yield strengths at all temperatures but a reduced fracture strain at RT. The H-MoW alloy also does not exhibit such substantial decreases on strength at elevated temperature as shown in H-W, which is good to the hightemperature performance of this alloy. The superior strength of H-MoW than H-W alloy hardly attributes to their grain sizes and melting temperature differences, since these two alloys show similar grain sizes (Fig. S1 in Supplementary Information) and the calculated melting point of H-MoW is only 25 C higher than that of H-W. Yield strengths (s y ), specific yield strengths (s s ) and fracture strains (ε f ) are summarized in Table 3. Comparing with the HfNbTaTiZr alloy [8], both H-W and H-MoW alloys show substantially improved yield strengths at all temperatures. This partly attributes to their increased melting points (2246 C for HfNbTaTiZr alloy, 2442 C for H-W alloy, and 2467 C for H-MoW alloy) when adding W and/or Mo. Specific yield strengths at all temperatures are also greatly improved, though H-W and H-MoW feature higher densities than HfNbTaTiZr. RT fracture strains of H-W and H-MoW are obviously decreased compared with HfNbTaTiZr (Table 3). Nevertheless, it is noticeable that both H-W and H-MoW alloys show balanced mechanical properties at high temperatures, e.g. H-MoW exhibits yield strength ~700 MPa and fracture strain >35% at 1200 C.

Strong strengthening effects of W and/or Mo additions can attribute to that i) W and/or Mo additions change the single BCC Experimental represents the ICP-OES-measured compositions of alloys. Note that the sum of atomic percentages of the six/seven elements is not 100%, because impurity elements <0.01 wt% are not listed. structure in HfNbTaTiZr into dual BCC structures which induces phase boundaries that can act as obstacles to dislocation motion and thus strengthen the alloy; and ii) W and/or Mo atoms increase the solid solution strengthening. This solid solution strengthening effect is rather evident when comparing H-W and H-MoW alloys, specifically, both alloys show similar dual phase structures and grain sizes but H-MoW that has Mo added exhibits higher yield strength.

Improving strength by dual phases has also been found in other HEAs. For example, it is reported that adjusting Zr, Al, and Ti compositions in AlNbTaTiVZr alloy can change the microstructure in the alloy into either single BCC or dual BCC, and the yield strength of the dual BCC alloy is higher than the single BCC one [32]. Another example is that replacing the W element in the MoN-bTaTiW alloy with Zr, the structure of alloy changes from single BCC of MoNbTaTiW to dual-phase BCC of MoNbTaTiWZr, and the yield strength increases [33,34].

Solid solution strengthening in the multi-component alloy can attribute to the atomic misfit and the modulus misfit between solute and solvent atoms [35e37]. And the solid solution strengthening effect Ds SSS can be expressed in the form of Eq. ( 11) [38]:
div.formula: Ds SSS ¼ X B 3=2 i c i 2=3 (11
div.p: where c i and B i are the content and hardening parameter of the solute i. B i is determined by the following equation [38]:

where G (G ¼ P c i G i ) is the shear modulus of the alloy, G i is the shear modulus of the element i, k i is the misfit parameter which is related to the modulus misfit h 0 i and atomic size misfit d i as shown in Eq. 13e15, and Z is a fitting constant [38].
div.formula: k i ¼ h 0 i þ ajd i j(13)
h 0 i ¼ h i 1 þ 0:5jh i j ; h i ¼ dG dc i 1 G ¼ 2 G i À G G i þ G (14
d i ¼ ds dc i 1 r i z s i À s HEAÀi r i(15)
div.p: where s i and s HEA-i are interatomic spacing of element i and HEA without element i. a is a parameter that accounts for the difference in the interaction forces between dislocations and solute atoms [38]. As for screw dislocations, a is between 3 and 16, and for edge dislocation, a is greater than 16. Calculated d i , h 0 i and k i of HfNbTaTiZr, H-W, and H-MoW alloys are given in Table 4. The data used for calculations are from Ref. [39].

As for equimolar ratio HfNbTaTiZr, H-W, and H-MoW alloys, the c i is a constant depending on the number of components. If ignoring the constant Z, the Eq. ( 11) can be simplified as: Table 5 shows that both G and P k 9=4 i c i of H-W and H-MoW alloys are higher than those of the original HfNbTaTiZr alloy, which indicates that the induced solid solution strengthening (Ds SSS ) would be higher for H-W and H-MoW as well. This strong solid solution strengthening is in a good agreement with the above shown mechanical testing results (Fig. 6 and Table 3), i.e. yield strengths of H-W and H-MoW alloys are substantially higher than HfNbTaTiZr, especially at higher temperatures. It is also noticeable that the calculated G and P k 9=4 i c i of H-MoW are greater than those of H-W, indicating the even stronger solid solution strengthening in H-MoW, which is also consistent with its higher yield strengths as shown in Fig. 6 and Table 3. Fig. 7 shows fracture surfaces of H-W and H-MoW alloys after compression tests at RT. It can be seen that both alloys exhibit typical brittle fracture, as clearly indicated by intergranular fractures (red circled areas) and river-patterns (blue circled areas) in higher magnification images in Fig. 7(b) and(d). Fig. 7(c) also shows a crack ~30 away from the loading direction on the fracture surface of the H-MoW sample, indicating the alloy experienced shear failure as well.
div.formula: Ds SSS fG X k 9=4 i c i 2=3(16)
div.p: H-W and H-MoW alloys exhibit no phase change after compressive tests at all high temperatures. This is clearly demonstrated in Fig. 8 using 1200 C samples as examples. As shown in Fig. 8(a), XRD results indicate that these two alloys generated no new phases during compression at 1200 C and there are still two disordered BCC phases (comparing with Fig. 2). The longitudinal cross-sections of these two alloys before and after tests are shown in Fig. 8(bee). The loading direction is vertical. It is clear that H-W shows constant dendrite microstructures before (Fig. 8(b)) and after (Fig. 8(c)) tests, though dendrites in H-W after hot pressing experienced coarsening and were stretched horizontally due to the parallel tensile stress. Similar coarsening and stretching of dendrites in H-MoW after tests can also be clearly seen in Fig. 8(e). Coarsening of dendrites in both alloys is reasonable since compressive tests at 1200 C can last for at least 0.25 h and that equates to annealing to some extent.

Good phase stabilities of H-W and H-MoW can attribute to their high entropies and therefore, at high temperatures, the entropy parts (-TDS) would contribute more to reduce the Gibbs free energy. However, it also should be noticed that currently observed phase stabilities at high temperature could be vanished after long time annealing, since there are multiple phases coexisted for H-W at <1000 C and for H-MoW at <1200 C, as shown in Fig. 1. In fact, for HfNbTaTiZr, the single BCC microstructure was maintained after compression tests at 800 C [20], but two (i.e. matrix BCC and Ta-Nb BCC) or three phases (i.e. matrix BCC, Ta-Nb BCC and Hf-Zr HCP) were observed after annealing at 500e900 C for 96 h [18,19]. Therefore, phase stabilities of H-W and H-MoW alloys at 800e1200 C are still need to be studied further.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: W and Mo were added to the HfNbTaTiZr alloy to improve its high-temperature performance. Crystal structures, microstructures, and mechanical properties of new RHEAs, HfNbTaTiZrW (H-W) and HfNbTaTiZrMoW (H-MoW) were studied. The following conclusions can be drawn:

(1) Both H-W and H-MoW exhibit two disordered BCC phases in each alloy, and they correspond to dendrite regions and interdendrite regions respectively. The dendrite BCC phase is rich in high melting point elements (W, Ta, and Nb) whereas the interdendrite BCC phase is rich in low melting point elements (Hf, Zr, and Ti). Elements segregations are even serious in H-W than in H-MoW, which leads to larger different between lattice constants of the two BCC phases in H-W.

figure.head: of 3 .
figure.figDesc: 291 Å. B area in Fig. 5(b) enriched with Hf, Zr, and Ti is determined as another BCC phase with a lattice parameter of 3.383 Å. A and B areas/phases are consistent with the dendrite and interdendrite regions in H-W alloy respectively. Similarly, C and D areas (Fig. 5 (c) and (d)) in the H-MoW alloy are rich with elements of high melting points and low melting points respectively, and they correspond to dendrite and interdendrite regions in the alloy. These two BCC phases are determined with lattice parameters of 3.267 Å and 3.355 Å respectively. TEM measured lattice parameters are well consistent with previous XRD measured values (Table

figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. (a) XRD patterns and (bee) Microstructures of H-W and H-MoW alloys after compressed at 1200 C.

Comparing with HfNbTaTiZr, H-W and H-MoW exhibit higher yield strengths and much balanced mechanical properties at high temperatures. The greatly improve strengths of H-W and H-MoW attribute to dual BCC structures and the strong solid solution strengthening effect induced by W and/or Mo additions.(3) H-W and H-MoW alloys show better resistance to the hightemperature softening compared with HfNbTaTiZr. No new phases were presented in H-W and H-MoW after compressions at high temperatures up to 1200 C, indicating good phase stabilities of new alloys.

note.p: . The experimental lattice parameter can be calculated from Bragg's Law: 2dsinq ¼ nl. Calculations are based on the first three strongest peaks of each XRD pattern, at least 4 sets of patterns were used for each alloy. The average lattice parameter of each solid solution was calculated using values generated from all related peaks. Measured average lattice parameters of the two BCC phases are 3.286 Å and 3.376 Å in H-W, and 3.273 Å and 3.348 Å in H-MoW. The error is ±~0.023 Å. As shown in Table1, the calculated values agree well with the XRD values, indicating lattice parameters in H-W and H-MoW alloys follow rule of mixtures, and also confirming that the two BCC phases in each alloy are disordered solid solutions.
